title: RS22674
content: President George W. Bush issued NSPD 51/HSPD 20 on National Continuity Policy in 2007 to ensure governing entities can recover from various operational interruptions like acts of nature, accidents, technological emergencies, and attacks. Continuity planning is seen as a good business practice in both government and private sectors. Continuity planning in the public and private sectors involves preparedness for emergencies and the resumption of normal operations. Federal continuity planning goes further to ensure the maintenance of constitutional government and essential activities without interruption. This includes supporting civil authority, aiding individuals and businesses, repairing infrastructure, and overseeing recovery efforts. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 outlines government continuity capabilities to ensure the preservation of constitutional government and the performance of essential functions during all conditions. It identifies eight National Essential Functions (NEFs) as the foundation for all continuity programs, including maintaining the functioning of government branches and providing visible leadership to the nation. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 outlines government continuity capabilities to ensure the preservation of constitutional government and the performance of essential functions during all conditions. It identifies eight National Essential Functions (NEFs) as the foundation for all continuity programs, including maintaining the functioning of government branches and providing visible leadership to the nation. The functions include defending the Constitution, maintaining relationships with foreign nations, protecting the homeland, responding to attacks, stabilizing the economy, and providing critical government services for the nation's health, safety, and welfare needs. Continuity planning is required to address potential interruptions in operations. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 mandates continuity planning in executive departments and agencies, emphasizing geographic dispersion and risk management principles. It requires the utilization of alternate facilities and staffing to ensure uninterrupted government functions. The directive incorporates planning assumptions and approaches from the private sector, designating the President to lead federal government activities for ensuring continuity. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 designates the President to lead federal government activities for ensuring constitutional government. The Assistant to the President for Homeland Security and Counterterrorism is the National Continuity Coordinator (NCC) who coordinates continuity policy development for executive branch departments and agencies. The NCC leads the development of a National Continuity Implementation Plan in consultation with appropriate departments and agencies. A Continuity Policy Coordination Committee (CPCC) is chaired by a Senior Director from the Homeland Security Council staff. The Homeland Security Council (HSC) staff appointed by the NCC is designated as the main forum for continuity policy coordination. The Secretary of Homeland Security is the President's lead agent for coordinating continuity operations. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 assigns federal agencies to categories based on their national security roles. The extent of authority for officials in charge of continuity coordination over executive branch agencies is unclear. Agency leaders must appoint a senior official as the continuity coordinator, develop plans for essential functions, and ensure readiness for emergencies. Continuity efforts align with national security roles and responsibilities. NSPD 51/HSPD 20 requires integration of continuity planning with state, local, territorial, and tribal governments, and private sector critical infrastructure owners to ensure essential services delivery during emergencies.
